thread.title: Tasmanian Devil population is being devastated by a facial tumour disease
thread.title_full: Tasmanian Devil population is being devastated by a facial tumour disease | Daily Mail Online

author: Wendy Gomersall For Mail On Sunday
title: Tasmanian Devil population is being devastated by a facial tumour disease
text:
5 shares 1
View
comments
'The population is being devastated by a facial tumour disease, and experts are fighting hard to prevent the animal’s extinction in the wild'
Everything I thought I knew about Tassie devils told me it wasn’t a good idea to step into their enclosure.
It didn’t help that one of the vicious-looking, beady-eyed critters was called Chomper.
I dithered while Greg Irons, animal rescuer and proprietor of Bonorong Wildlife Sanctuary near Hobart in glorious Tasmania, did his best to encourage me to join him in the pen.
Never has an animal been more maligned than this little carnivorous marsupial, he assured me. And as if to prove how much worse its bark – or rather spitty snarl, growl and scream – is than its bite, Chomper waddled over to Greg and scrambled up into his lap for a cuddle.
Let’s do it, I decided, gingerly walking over to Greg as Chomper and chum Pee Wee turned their heads in our direction. I held my breath…
Tasmanian devils are in trouble. The population is being devastated by a facial tumour disease, and experts are fighting hard to prevent the animal’s extinction in the wild.
Publicity about their plight has boosted interest in Tasmania itself.
Off the coast of southern Australia, it can be overlooked by international tourists but it is a brilliant destination thanks to stunning landscapes in a great outdoors made for hiking, cycling, sailing and canyoning.
 2 Next Hollywood's biggest stars, the delights of North Korea and... From Rihanna's beloved Caribbean isle to the Beckhams'... The five-smile resort: How TV presenter Anna Williamson's... Who's laughing now? Hyenas left with their tails between... Revealed: One million fewer tourists visiting Tunisia... Take the bracing Bonnet Island Experience ( bonnetisland.com.au ) cruise from Strahan to see penguins returning to their babies at dusk and watch the birdies on a Gordon River cruise with World Heritage Cruises.
Head for idyllic Bruny Island ( www.brunyislandlongweekend.com.au ) for a weekend looking for echidnas, kookaburras and seals (and eating fresh crayfish from the pristine waters).
There are quolls and wombats, wallabies, kangaroos, parrots and platypuses. But top of the list of must-sees these days is the Sarcophilus harrisii, aka the Tasmanian devil – Tasmania is even shaped a bit like a devil’s head.
Under threat: Two of the devils at Bonorong. Wendy Gomersall said: 'Tasmanian devils are in trouble'
If you’re not lucky enough to see one in the wild, you’re sure to encounter them at Bonorong, a magnet for all animal-lovers.
And patently no one’s told Chomper and Pee Wee they’re meant to be vicious, ultra-aggressive beasties waiting to rip your arm off at the first opportunity.
They did not make a squeak as my niece Holly and I padded into their enclosure. They did, however, exhibit their displeasure by standing on the spot and trembling violently, their plump rumps vibrating and their dark, sticking-up fur making them look like angry little punk rockers.
We were almost disappointed not to have been torn to shred. Were they afraid of us? I asked Greg.
No, they were reacting to our smell, he said, reaching down just in time to shoo away Chomper who, having taken advantage of my distraction, was making a beeline for my exposed ankle.
Sneaky little devils…
TRAVEL FACTS A 15-day self-drive holiday to Tasmania including international return flights from the UK to Hobart, car hire, accommodation, some meals and a number of wildlife experiences costs from £2,875pp.
Contact Wildlife & Wilderness ( wildlifewilderness.com , 01625 838225). Valid for travel between October 1, 2015 and October 1, 2016. For more ideas on visiting Tasmania, go to tasmanianodyssey.com or call 01534 735449.
